title: What are the unusual phenomena observed in mesmerism and hypnotism experiments in the late 19th century?
first_phrase: The following text discusses the various experiences observed in subjects under different states of hypnosis. It is stated that some subjects experienced sensations that were only suggested to their minds, while others forgot their names or certain numbers but could still speak. In some cases, subjects experienced extreme stiffness in their muscles, while retaining no memory of their actions after returning to consciousness. The author notes that these experiments shed light on the separation between conscious and unconscious intelligence, but refrains from commenting on the underlying force behind the observed phenomena. The text was written by Doctor Marc Dufour, and references the work of Professor Ileidenlmin and other German professors who conducted experiments on magnetism.

Assurément ces expériences sont très facilitées par la séparation aisée qui peut s’opérer, chez certains sujets, entre l’action de l’intelligence consciente et l’action de l’intelligence inconsciente, l’une pouvant être supprimée tandis que l’autre fonctionne et inversement; mais je ne me prononce absolument pas sur la nature de l’action fluide, volonté, etc., qui est à la base de ces phénomènes (2) et dont l’étude sera sans doute l’objet de travaux ultérieurs. last_phrase: In conclusion, these experiments on somnambulism and hypnotism highlight the complexity of the human mind and the need for careful discernment when conducting such research. The results obtained through fascination expérimentale have been particularly fruitful, revealing the power of the operator's influence on the subject. However, caution must be exercised in interpreting the results and further studies will be necessary to fully understand the underlying mechanisms at work. As always, the practice of magnétisme must be approached with care and respect for the well-being of the subjects involved.
